subject: RE: [junit] Classpath troubleshooting JUnit 3.8.1, Redhat 9, JDK 1.4.1_02/01
msgSnippet: texanworker I would be interested to know how you are running junit.  I too have a classpath problem that I cannot figure out.  I am running builds with ant
messageBody:
texanworker

I would be interested to know how you are running junit. I too have a
classpath problem that I cannot figure out. I am running builds with ant
and have a junit target.

I have organized my test classes in a mirror tree to my java

source/myco/tsr/test/...
source/myco/tsr/java/...

My ant target is

<target name="unitTest" depends="clean,prepare,compile">

<echo> </echo>

<echo>#####################################################################<
/echo>
<echo>#
#</echo>
<echo># Unit Testing ${server} server for the ${app.name} application
</echo>
<echo>#
#</echo>

<echo>#####################################################################<
/echo>
<echo> </echo>


<junit printsummary="on" dir="${deploy.home}/test" >

<formatter type="plain" usefile="false" />
<test name="test.myco.tsr.AllTests" />

<classpath>
<pathelement location="${app.home};${junit.home}" />
<pathelement location="${classpath}" />
</classpath>

</junit>

</target>

Previous posts have told me that using the classpath property in a
pathelement is wrong
but according to Orielly Ant the definitive Guide the Junit target does not
take a
classpath attribute. It only contains 0,1, more classpath elements. It seem
very inefficient
to consolidate all the path dirs under classpath in the start of my ant
script only to have
to do it again because the junit target does not have a classpath attribute.

I am not on the same platform as you but would like to know specifically
what the
output from the junit step means

I am runnig win 2000k, ant1.5, junit3.8.1, java 1.3.1_01. and tomcat 4.1.18

My ant build output is

[junit] dir attribute ignored if running in the same VM
[junit] Running test.myco.tsr.AllTests
[junit] Tests run: 1, Failures: 0, Errors: 1, Time elapsed: 0 sec
[junit] Testsuite: test.myco.tsr.AllTests
[junit] Tests run: 1, Failures: 0, Errors: 1, Time elapsed: 0 sec

[junit] Caused an ERROR
[junit] test.myco.tsr.AllTests
[junit] java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: test.myco.tsr.AllTests

Does the line "[junit] Running test.myco.tsr.AllTests" mean that it found
my test cases? The error indicates the opposite.

Is your setup bombing because it can't find junit.jar or your test
class(es)?



Thanks

Michael




-----Original Message-----
From: texanworker [mailto:texanworker@...]
Sent: Thursday, May 29, 2003 3:18 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Classpath troubleshooting JUnit 3.8.1, Redhat 9, JDK
1.4.1_02/01


I installed Redhat 9, junit 3.8.1, and two JDK's -- 1.4.1 versions 01
and 02.

Regardless of how I set classpath, the TestRunner will run and
find no classes.

It is puzzling that junit.jar can be found in order to run the
TestRunner class, but it cannot find the junit.samples.AllTests
class.

A few specific questions:
1) I have tried copying junit.jar to various locations. It
starts out in the junit3.8.1 directory. Is the standard procedure
to use that directory as its home, or is it normally moved to the
JDK lib directory. Would this make any difference?

2) On Redhat 8.0, the swingui TestRunner could find and run
tests on some built-in classes, such as junit.samples.money.MoneyTest.
Now with Redhat 9, a clean install with no files from the old
system, no test classes can be found -- not VectorTest, not
money.MoneyTest, not samples.AllTests, nor tests.AllTests. Does
anyone know why these were found in Redhat 8 but not Redhat 9?

3) Is there any kind of minimum hardware requirement? I haven't
seen one in the documentation, but I'm running this on a bad
machine, namely a 300 MHz x86 with 256 MB RAM.

4) The documentation for the installation process gives exactly
one troubleshooting tip. It advises that if the initial tests do
not run, one should check to make sure that the junit.jar is on
the classpath. If one is certain that junit.jar IS on the classpath
but it's still not working, one seems to be out of luck. Are there
any other JUnit troubleshooting documents or sources?

5) Dave Astels posted earlier that he is using Redhat 9, Java 1.4.1
01, and junit 3.8.1. Are there other Linux JUnit users who can
compare their configurations, and possibly post configuration files
such as .bashrc, etc.?

Thanks
